Thyme.ly

Because there's no time like the present

HIGHLIGHTS

Features you'll love

Simple

Thyme.ly was designed with you in mind. It comes integrated with macOS and ready to go right out the box.

Smart

Thyme.ly utilizes real-time machine learning to give you a personalized, customizable, "smart" productivity manager.

Private

Thyme.ly stores your activity data on your local disk. We do not share, store, or send user-specific activity data.

Open Source

Thyme.ly is an open source project. Feel free to check out our Github page. Contributions welcome!

Github
FEATURES

Do more with Thyme.ly

  • Machine Learning
  • Pomodoro Timer
  • Google Calendar
  • Live Analytics

Track your daily productivity

And watch Thyme.ly categorize your activities so you don't have to

Unlike other productivity managers, Thyme.ly can distinguish the productivity level of different pages within one website.

Spend a lot of time on YouTube learning JavaScript frameworks for your job? No problem, Thyme.ly’s machine learning can tell the difference between that (productive) and you checking out the Royal Wedding (probably distracting, though we can’t blame you)!

Optimize your time management

Customizable intervals for consistent work-break schedules all day

Studies show that the Pomodoro technique helps boost overall productivity. So our customizable Pomodoro timer reminds you when to take a break and do more by doing less. Best of all, Thyme.ly automatically pauses during Pomodoro breaks, so feel free to unwind with your favorite cute cat gifs.

Never Forget a Scheduled Meeting

Deep in the zone and lost track of time? Don't worry, Thyme.ly's got your back!

Sign in with Google (optional) and Thyme.ly will alert you when a Google Calendar event is coming up.

Track your daily productivity

Are you a morning person? Night owl? Not sure? Find new insights about your productivity with our live data visualizations.

FAQ

Frequently Asked Questions

How is Thyme.ly monitoring my activity?

Thyme.ly periodically gets data from your computer about your current active window (e.g., "Google Chrome", "Sublime Text") and the window title (e.g., "GitHub", "YouTube"). Thyme.ly then uses that data in ways that help you monitor your productivity. That's it!

How is Thyme.ly "learning" my activity perferences?

It's no fun having to categorize every website you visit to get an accurate productivity score. Thyme.ly uses machine learning to help predict whether a website is productive or distracting. It does this by analyzing how all users are categorizing websites and uses that to predict productivity.

When you categorize an app as productive or distracting, Thyme.ly will remember this categorization. The next time you use that app, Thyme.ly will categorize this app automatically. This means Thyme.ly will get smarter the more you use it! Pretty soon, you won't have to manually categorize those sorts of apps at all!

Where is Thyme.ly storing my activity data?

Thyme.ly stores most of your activity data in a local database file in your own computer. This data is never sent to the cloud or seen by us.

When you categorize an activity as productive or distracting, this categorization is sent to the cloud database along with a user id to help Thyme.ly make more accurate predictions in the future.

However, if you are uncomfortable with certain classifications being sent to the cloud, pressing "delete" on the activity card triggers its deletion from the database. Of course, you can pause the activity monitor at any time.

What technologies does Thyme.ly use?

Thyme.ly is essentially two apps in one! The Thyme.ly client uses React with Redux to render views. The client is also wrapped in Electron, an library developed by Github that allows developers to create cross-platform desktop apps using JavaScript. The client also uses a SQLite database for local storage.

The Thyme.ly server runs Node.js using the Express web framework. It uses a PostgreSQL database. The server also has a web worker that uses Puppeteer/Headless Chrome to bulk scrape productive and distracting website titles. Finally, the server's machine learning uses the Naive Bayes Classifier algorithm.
